title-group.article-title: Rapid access microscopy and real-time case discussion via a secure messaging app improves diagnostic accuracy and management of acute hot swollen joints

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Patients with acute swollen joints are often presumed to have septic arthritis, leading to intravenous antibiotics and arthroscopic washout. Previously at our centre, joint fluid aspirates often lacked crystal analysis, resulting in excess culture-negative septic arthritis diagnoses. We developed a ‘Hot Joint Pathway’, hypothesising that since acute crystal arthropathy can be misdiagnosed as ‘culture-negative septic arthritis’, introducing the pathway would improve diagnostic accuracy.

This pathway provides a structured approach for investigating acutely swollen joints, distinguishing septic arthritis from crystal arthritis. Key features include a secure messaging app for multidisciplinary discussion and rheumatology-led point-of-care polarised light microscopy (POC PLM) <24 hours 6 days per week. A service evaluation of hospital inpatient data identified patients labelled with septic arthritis admitted between two periods: before (1 January 2019–30 November 2020) and after (27 September 2022–29 February 2024) pathway implementation. Emergency department (ED) patients discussed via the app were also analysed (27 September 2022–25 September 2023).

Among ED patients, 92% received rheumatology input, and 100% underwent joint aspiration with rheumatologist-led crystal analysis in <24 hours. 68% avoided hospital admission, receiving same-day discharge. Of these, 53% were diagnosed with crystal arthropathy and were discharged with planned outpatient follow-up.

Diagnostic accuracy increased for inpatients following pathway introduction. Joint aspirates increased from 50% to 76% (p=0.034). Culture-negative cases of septic arthritis reduced from 34% to 17% and culture positive cases increased from 41% to 76% (p<0.005). Crystal analysis increased from 19% to 28%. Positive blood cultures increased from 28% to 41%. Mean length of stay decreased from 26 to 23 days.

A structured care pathway combining rheumatology-led POC PLM and multidisciplinary discussion increases diagnostic accuracy, facilitates admission avoidance and reduces hospital stay for patients with acute swollen joints. Rheumatology-led PLM is essential for the success of this pathway.

caption.title: WHAT IS ALREADY KNOWN ON THIS TOPIC

list-item.p: Integration of rheumatologist-led POC PLM into a structured care pathway for use in the emergency department rapidly identified crystal arthropathies. Increased diagnostic accuracy of these cases improved patient outcomes and resulted in substantial admission avoidance.

sec.title: HOW THIS STUDY MIGHT AFFECT RESEARCH, PRACTICE OR POLICY

list-item.p: The ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ can be feasibly implemented across healthcare institutions globally by leveraging widespread access to a microscope and smartphone. Access to a polarised light microscope is essential to facilitate rheumatologist-led POC PLM. The pathway has important implications for healthcare policy by optimising hospital resources and encouraging antimicrobial stewardship to address the growing threat of antibiotic resistance.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Acute hot swollen joints are diagnostically challenging, due to their broad differential diagnoses, ranging from crystal arthropathy, manageable in the community, to septic arthritis, a condition with significant morbidity and mortality. Point-of-care (POC) polarised light microscopy (PLM) to detect monosodium urate (MSU) and calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals is the gold standard for diagnosis of crystal arthropathy, as outlined by both the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) and European League Against Rheumatism (EULAR).1 2 Rheumatologist-led POC PLM can rapidly diagnose a crystal arthropathy, facilitating discharge with a management plan. In contrast, cases of septic arthritis are diagnosed by positive synovial fluid cultures, which take days to yield results and require admission for intravenous antibiotics and potential arthroscopic washout.3

Despite guidelines advocating for rheumatologist-led crystal analysis, considerable variation in practice remains and crystal analysis is often omitted in the investigation of acute swollen joints in the emergency department (ED) and inpatient setting.4 The lack of POC PLM for these patients often results in unnecessary admissions for empirical intravenous antibiotics while awaiting culture results to confirm septic arthritis.5 Multiple studies have reported that crystal arthropathy is often misdiagnosed as septic arthritis, with one analysis finding that gout patients were 2.6 times more likely to be diagnosed with septic arthritis and subject to potentially unnecessary admission and intravenous antibiotics compared with controls.6

Our study describes the development and implementation of a ‘Hot Joint Pathway’, which aimed to improve the diagnostic accuracy of acute swollen joints by incorporating rapid access rheumatologist-led POC PLM into a structured workup. Our aim was to improve patient outcomes by rapidly identifying crystal arthropathies that would otherwise have been treated as culture-negative septic arthritis.

sec.title: Baseline measurement
sec.p: Rheumatologists in our institution frequently received consultation requests for patients diagnosed with culture-negative septic arthritis, often after intravenous antibiotics had been initiated. We observed that aspiration of synovial fluid with rheumatology-led POC PLM was often omitted from initial investigations. This was clinically significant because many of these cases met the criteria for crystal arthropathy.

A baseline audit of hospital inpatient enquiry (HIPE) data identified 35 patients admitted with a label of septic arthritis from 1 January 2019 to 30 November 2020. Three miscoded cases were excluded. POC PLM and diagnostic accuracy were assessed. Culture-negative septic arthritis cases were defined as cases where synovial fluid or tissue cultures were negative or reported as contaminants with subsequent negative samples. Of the 32 patients identified, only 6 patients were assessed with PLM. Patient charts were reviewed by a rheumatology specialist registrar. Nine patients were identified where an alternative diagnosis to septic arthritis was more likely, seven of whom were nonetheless treated for septic arthritis with intravenous antibiotics without a positive joint or blood culture. Four of these patients had features consistent with a diagnosis of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) arthritis, with a further two highly suspicious for a diagnosis of gout.

To further assess diagnostic accuracy, we reviewed 26 cases that underwent crystal analysis by both rheumatology-led POC PLM and the hospital laboratory (1 December 2021–1 October 2024). The laboratory took a mean average of 5.6 days whereas rheumatology-led POC PLM reported results in <24 hours (p<0.00001). 46% (12/26) of cases were reported as negative for crystals by the laboratory but reported positive when analysed by a rheumatologist. Of these, 11 cases were positive for CPP crystals. Overall, inconsistencies were found in 16/26 of cases, with CPP crystals often omitted from laboratory reports. Cohen’s kappa coefficient (κ=0.0) indicated no agreement beyond chance, and McNemar’s test (p=0.0078) confirmed a statistically significant difference in diagnostic classifications between the two methods. This unpublished preliminary study further emphasised the value of implementing rheumatologist-led POC PLM for efficient and accurate diagnoses of acute swollen joints.7

sec.title: Design and strategy
sec.p: Our baseline inpatient audit highlighted diagnostic inaccuracies, particularly in culture-negative septic arthritis cases. Since acute hot joints present to the ED, we focused efforts on improving diagnosis at the initial point of presentation. Stakeholders from rheumatology, ED, infectious disease and orthopaedics collaborated via four in-person meetings and regular email communication to establish best practice for management of acute swollen joints in the ED. This group included consultants and trainees from each specialty to ensure a variety of perspectives were considered. Strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats analysis identified barriers to introducing a ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ which helped troubleshoot difficulties. Two major Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-based (SMART) aims were agreed on: (1) develop a novel, multidisciplinary and timely approach to manage acute swollen joints in the ED and (2) reduce the number of inpatients with a discharge diagnosis of culture-negative septic arthritis. Key guidelines, including the French recommendations on the management of septic arthritis in the adult native joint, guideline for management of septic arthritis in native joints, ACR/EULAR Gout Classification criteria and EULAR recommendations for diagnosis of crystal arthropathy were used to benchmark and standardise the pathway.1 2 8 9 In light of this, rheumatologist-led POC PLM was included with an aim for sample analysis within 24 hours 6 days per week, with faster turnaround during daytime hours. To ensure accurate crystal analysis, the pathway required red-compensated PLM with a circular rotating stage, as used in our hospital, to assess birefringence and eliminate artefacts. Studies have reported significant interobserver variability of MSU and CPP crystal identification depending on the level of training of laboratory staff or rheumatologists.1 2 10 Therefore, only rheumatology specialist registrars or consultants trained in PLM were incorporated into the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’.11

Real-time consultant-led case discussion was essential for timely PLM and discharge decisions. We implemented Siilo, a free secure medical messaging app which complies with all European Union (EU) General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) healthcare security and compliance requirements, to facilitate multidisciplinary collaboration (figure 4). Many doctors were already using Siilo for secure communication within our hospital, minimising the need for behavioural change.

The final consensus led to the development of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ which included: (1) baseline blood cultures, (2) early joint aspiration before antibiotic administration where clinically appropriate and (3) real-time case discussion via Siilo to organise rheumatologist-led PLM within 24 hours 6 days per week (figure 1, figure 4). In cases of ‘dry taps’ or suspected tenosynovitis, ultrasound-guided joint aspiration was considered and multidisciplinary decision-making was supported via Siilo. Other key elements of the pathway were followed where feasible. We collaborated with our hospital’s IT department to integrate the pathway into our ‘patient centre’ software, which is used by staff to review clinical information. This enabled easy access and promoted awareness for those reviewing patients in the ED.

caption.title: The ‘Hot Joint Pathway’. FBC, full blood count; CRP, C reactive protein; PT, prothrombin time; SIRS, systemic inflammatory response syndrome; INR, international normalised ratio; ED, emergency department; WCC, white cell count; EM, emergency medicine.

sec.title: Assessing impact
sec.p: ED recorded 25 patients recruited to the pathway over two 6 monthly cycles from 27 September 2022 to 25 September 2023. The initial cycle showed a decrease in patients recruited to the pathway after the 3 monthly staff changeover. Therefore, ED-led teaching sessions were implemented after each changeover to sustain awareness and adherence of the pathway.

A reaudit of inpatients admitted with a label of septic arthritis was completed after the pathway had been introduced. The pathway was launched on 27 September 2022. 32 cases admitted between 27 September 2022 and 29 February 2024 were identified and 3 were excluded for incorrect coding. Key outcomes such as rheumatologist-led POC PLM, blood cultures, joint aspirations, synovial culture and length of stay were assessed. Cases were also reviewed independently by two consultant rheumatologists to assess the diagnostic accuracy of septic arthritis cases.

Fisher’s exact test was applied to categorical variables to assess differences in proportion. Continuous data were assessed using a bootstrapped independent t-test. A p<0.05 was considered statistically significant. Statistical analysis was performed using IBM SPSS Statistics V.30.0.0.

sec.title: Comparison of inpatient septic arthritis cases pre and post ‘Hot Joint Pathway’
Patient characteristics
sec.p: The baseline audit recorded 32 patients with a discharge diagnosis of septic arthritis across a 23-month period. 71% were medical admissions and 29% were surgical admissions. Age ranged from 20 to 101 years and mean age was 59 years. Reaudit after introduction of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ recorded 29 patients across a 17-month period, 35% of which were medical admissions and 66% were surgical admissions. Age ranged from 31 to 86 years and mean age was 58 years. The most common joint affected pre and post pathway was the knee, making up 35% of patients prepathway and 55% postpathway. The mean average length of hospital admission for all patients before the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ was 26 days (95% CI 17 to 37) which decreased to 23 days (95% CI 15 to 31) after its introduction. The mean difference in length of stay was 3.23 days (95% CI −9 to 16).

sec.title: Imaging
sec.p: All patients before and after introduction of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ received imaging of the affected joint. Before the introduction of the pathway, 18 patients had reported changes of osteoarthritis (56%), there was reported chondrocalcinosis in 3/32 (9%) of patients and one additional patient’s imaging showed a subtle change of likely chondrocalcinosis, which was not reported. Postpathway, 38% (11/29) of patients had reported features of osteoarthritis and 10% (3/29) had reported features of chondrocalcinosis.

sec.title: Joint aspirations, crystal analysis, synovial culture and blood cultures
sec.p: The proportion of culture-positive septic arthritis cases increased significantly following pathway implementation, rising from 41% prepathway to 76% postpathway (p≤0.009, 2-sided; p≤0.005, 1-sided) (figure 2). The most common organism isolated from culture positive cases in both groups was Staphylococcus species (online supplemental table 1).

caption.title: Joint aspirations, culture positive and culture-negative inpatient cases pre versus post introduction of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’. Joint aspirations increased from 50% (16/32) prepathway to 76% (22/29) postpathway (p=0.034, 1-sided). Culture positive cases increased from 41% (95% CI 23.6% to 57.6%) to 76% (95% CI 60.4% to 91.6%) (p=0.009, 2-sided). Culture-negative cases decreased from 34% to 17% (p=0.155, 2-sided).

sec.p: Inpatient joint aspirates increased from 50% prepathway to 76% postpathway, suggesting improved adherence to best practice (figure 2). Fisher’s exact test indicated a trend towards statistical significance (p=0.063, 2-sided), with a significant result using a one sided test (p=0.034).

Interestingly, 50% (16/32) of inpatients prepathway did not have joint aspirations, although seven of these patients had a surgical specimen sent to the laboratory from arthroscopic washout. This suggests that a proportion of patients proceeded directly to theatre without diagnostic arthrocentesis. In contrast, 24% (7/29) of hot swollen joints were not aspirated postpathway. Of these, five had a sample sent to the laboratory from washout.

Crystal analysis of inpatient synovial fluid samples increased from 19% (6/32) to 28% (8/29) (p=0.545, 2-sided; p=0.303, 1-sided). Online supplemental table 2 provides a detailed breakdown, demonstrating a shift towards rheumatology-led POC PLM for crystal detection of inpatient aspirates after introduction of the pathway.

Overall, positive blood cultures were detected in 9/32 (28%) cases prepathway which increased to 12/29 (41%) cases postpathway (p=0.296, 2-sided; p=0.207, 1-sided). The most commonly isolated organism was Staphylococcus species in both groups (online supplemental table 3).

sec.title: ED data after implementation of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’
sec.p: 25 patients were managed using the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ over a 12-month period (figure 3). Of these, 92% received rheumatology input, and 100% underwent joint aspiration by an ED doctor with rheumatology-led crystal analysis within 24 hours. 68% (17/25) avoided hospital admission, receiving same-day discharge. Of these, 53% (9/17) received a same-day diagnosis of crystal arthropathy and were discharged with planned rheumatology outpatient follow-up. 16% (4/25) of cases received a discharge diagnosis of septic arthritis, whereas 44% were diagnosed with crystal arthropathy (11/25), of which 3/25 were calcium pyrophosphate deposition (CPPD) and 8/25 gout.

caption.title: Outcome of cases reviewed via the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ in the emergency department. CPPD, calcium pyrophosphate deposition; OA, osteoarthritis.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Introduction of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ was associated with improved diagnostic accuracy of acute swollen joints for inpatients. Joint aspiration rates and culture positive septic arthritis cases increased significantly (p=0.034 and p≤0.005, respectively), while other findings such as a 17% reduction in culture-negative septic arthritis cases and 13% rise in positive blood cultures were clinically meaningful but not statistically significant (table 1). Positive synovial fluid culture is crucial in confirming a diagnosis of septic arthritis, with studies reporting that 80% of non-gonococcal septic arthritis cases are culture positive.12 Culture-negative cases can be attributed to misdiagnoses and antibiotic administration before joint aspiration, both of which are addressed by the pathway. While culture-negative cases can also be explained by low bacterial loads and variation in culture technique, our study indicates that the pathway aids successful identification of crystal arthropathy, thus reducing unnecessary admissions. The increase in positive blood cultures is notable because 70% of septic arthritis cases result from bacteraemia due to the lack of protective basement membrane in joints.12 This rise reflects the pathway’s emphasis on preantibiotic cultures, even in afebrile cases, increasing the likelihood of detecting positive results. The literature consistently emphasises the diagnostic challenge of confirming septic arthritis and notes the importance of early joint aspiration for synovial fluid culture, crystal analysis and blood cultures.9 13

caption.title: Summary of inpatient cases and percentage changes pre and post pathway for positive blood cultures, joint aspirates, crystal analysis, culture-negative and culture positive septic arthritis cases

sec.p: Improved diagnostic accuracy was also observed in the ED with 68% of patients avoiding admission; 53% of whom received a same day diagnosis of crystal arthropathy. Excluding septic arthritis is critical due to its high morbidity. However, our data showed that only 16% (4/25) of cases presenting to ED with an acute swollen joint were confirmed cases. One meta-analysis demonstrated similar results; only 27% of acute swollen joints assessed in the ED were confirmed as non-gonococcal septic arthritis.14 Gout is more common than septic arthritis (0.58–2.89 per 1000 person-years vs 0.02–0.10 cases per 1000 person-years) and the two conditions may rarely coexist, presenting a unique diagnostic challenge.15 16 One inpatient reviewed postpathway was diagnosed with concomitant septic arthritis and CPPD, demonstrating the increased risk of septic arthritis in crystal arthropathy due to inflammation of the synovial membrane and associated comorbidities.6 The ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ addresses this by promoting early POC PLM and multidisciplinary collaboration. The presence of crystals does not exclude septic arthritis; however, early discussion between rheumatology, orthopaedics and infectious disease specialists facilitates informed decision-making regarding admission, antimicrobial therapy and invasive procedures in such cases. Overall, the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ provides guidance on timely investigations to ensure septic arthritis is promptly excluded while accounting for other differential diagnoses.

Rheumatologist-led POC PLM provides rapid information, which can be clinically correlated to eliminate septic arthritis (figure 4). This eliminates the delays associated with laboratory processing and culture results, thus reducing diagnostic delay. In cases where immediate POC PLM is not feasible, samples are refrigerated at 4°C until analysis can take place. Studies have shown that refrigeration maintains crystal integrity for up to 72 hours.17 18 Bernal et al reported that while non-PLM can detect crystals, particularly for MSU (κ=0.88), interobserver agreement was lower for CPP crystals (κ=0.69), emphasising the need for PLM.19 In centres lacking PLM, regular light microscopy may serve as a useful interim by encouraging behavioural change and future investment in PLM. However, given the complexity of CPPD, PLM should be prioritised to ensure timely diagnosis and support future research into this evolving field of medicine.

caption.title: Example of multidisciplinary case discussion between ED and rheumatology via Siilo in the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’. This screenshot demonstrates real-time communication, including POC PLM results and management advice to facilitate rapid diagnosis and decision-making. ED, emergency department; POC PLM, point-of-care polarised light microscopy. ETOH, alcohol; ROM, range of motion.

sec.p: The ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ prompts early blood cultures and joint aspiration prior to antibiotic administration, supporting the growing need for robust antimicrobial stewardship in hospitals. Antibiotic resistance is a global crisis, forecast to cause 1.91 million attributable deaths and 8.22 million associated deaths by 2050.20 Cultures and susceptibility testing are essential for diagnosis of septic arthritis, targeted antibiotic therapy and surveillance of resistance. Administering antibiotics before joint aspiration decreases synovial white cell counts, polymorphonuclear cells and culture positive cases, therefore, reducing diagnostic accuracy.21 The pathway enables rapid POC PLM, which reduces misdiagnoses of culture-negative septic arthritis and avoids unnecessary intravenous antibiotics. This is particularly relevant, as antibiotic overconsumption is a major driver for evolution of resistant microbes.22 The pathway encourages best practice by combining early input from infectious disease specialists and aligning with WHO guidelines to promote targeted, evidence-based antibiotic use.23

The ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ improved healthcare efficiency by reducing inpatient length of stay and facilitating same day discharge in the ED. Although not statistically significant, length of stay for septic arthritis cases fell from 26 to 23 days, approaching the national average.24 In the ED, 68% (17/25) of patients assessed through the pathway avoided admission altogether, as they were rapidly diagnosed as crystal or other forms of arthritis suitable for management in the community. In contrast, national HIPE data report mean stays of 17.1 days and 9.2 days for complex and less complex cases of bone disease and arthropathies, including gout and CPPD.24 These findings demonstrate the pathway’s effectiveness in reducing length of stay and avoiding admission whenever possible.25 26

The detection of crystal arthropathy and associated admission avoidance improved patient outcomes by reducing the use of unnecessary intravenous antibiotics and arthroscopic washouts. Arthroscopic washouts are invasive procedures completed under general anaesthetic, associated with significant risk especially in elderly patients with comorbidities.27 Effective management of gout is also important due to its association with chronic kidney disease, diabetes, hypertension and dyslipidaemia.28 Similarly, failure to identify CPPD can have notable consequences in younger patient cohorts, due to underlying aetiology such as haemochromatosis, hypomagnesaemia and hyperparathyroidism.29 30 Overall, timely detection and management of crystal arthropathy aligns with patient-centred clinical care.

Finally, the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ is simple, globally scalable and supports clinicians at all levels. Standardised care pathways improve patient outcomes by supporting evidence-based practice, reducing inconsistencies, streamlining resources and encouraging multidisciplinary collaboration. The pathway also served as an educational tool, reinforcing crystal recognition with visual reference and experiential learning via case-based discussion. Informal feedback indicated increased clinician confidence in managing hot swollen joints. A similar UK-based ‘Hot Swollen Joint Bundle’, developed using British Society for Rheumatology (BSR) guidelines, reduced length of stay and led to increased frequency of joint aspirates and blood cultures.31 These outcomes mirror our own findings and highlight the global challenge of improving diagnostic accuracy in acute swollen joints.32 Our hospital’s ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ is novel due to guaranteed rheumatologist-led POC PLM within 24 hours, outlined using a simple step-by-step format which supports clinicians irrespective of their level of training. Implementation only requires a microscope and free secure messaging app like Siilo. Accurate crystal analysis requires a circular rotating stage and red compensator, which are essential for assessing birefringence. Many institutions already possess microscopes with polarising light functionality; therefore, upgrading existing equipment may help facilitate this pathway. While we acknowledge developing countries experience increased barriers to accessing and maintaining medical devices, microscopes are fundamental to hospital infrastructure globally.33 Overall, the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ is inexpensive and translatable, as smartphone use and existing microscope infrastructure make widespread implementation achievable.34

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: The positive change associated with the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ has not come without limitations. We recognise that PLM is associated with variations in specificity and sensitivity for crystal detection despite our efforts to mitigate this by ensuring PLM was completed by a trained rheumatologist.10 In Ireland, crystal analysis is a supervised core procedure within rheumatology training; however, training can vary based on departmental culture in different hospitals. Although training is available through national registrar days and conference-facilitated courses, these variations highlight how a standardised certification in crystal analysis may ensure consistency among the clinicians leading this pathway.

Not all patients presenting to ED with acute swollen joints were recruited to the pathway, as demonstrated by inpatient cases detected during the same time period. We have discussed this issue in ongoing multidisciplinary meetings. Decreased awareness of the pathway during staff changeover, difficulty aspirating joints, time pressure and competence of trainees were identified as barriers.

The small sample size may impact the generalisability of this study, which reflects the data of a single institution. To ensure validity, we carefully handled our data, defined clear eligibility and exclusion criteria and adhered to strict study time frames.35 Future annual reaudits will monitor sustained integration into clinical workflows and include a multidisciplinary survey to assess educational impact and clinician confidence in managing acute swollen joints. Further research should incorporate baseline ED data and include larger multicentre datasets to enhance statistical power and assess applicability to diverse healthcare settings.

While our centre has access to a microscope located within the rheumatology department, we acknowledge that other centres may face barriers to implementing rheumatology-led POC PLM. These include obtaining laboratory accreditation to have equipment located in the department, broken equipment, lack of funding and an increased need for training in rheumatology-led POC PLM.

While the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ was a pilot study focused on engaging the ED, it has also highlighted a need for stronger collaboration with orthopaedics. Only a proportion of theatre samples from inpatients with suspected septic arthritis were sent for crystal analysis, and this only marginally improved following introduction of the pathway. Building on the success of engaging ED, we plan on liaising with orthopaedics to increase rheumatology POC PLM analysis of synovial samples from inpatient septic arthritis cases.

We are committed to ongoing multidisciplinary collaboration, joint aspiration teaching and awareness campaigns to sustain the positive impact of the ‘Hot Joint Pathway’. We acknowledge that quality improvement initiatives require long-lasting efforts and aim to continue these while encouraging use of the pathway in other institutions.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The ‘Hot Joint Pathway’ supports clinicians to effectively diagnose acute swollen joints. The use of a structured pathway based on best practice guidelines, rheumatologist-led POC PLM, multidisciplinary involvement and a patient-centred approach has substantially improved patient outcomes and streamlined healthcare resources. We believe integration of rheumatologist-led POC PLM has been integral to the success of this pathway and hope to encourage its use in other hospitals.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The author would like to sincerely thank the multidisciplinary team involved in developing and implementing the pathway as well as all the patients involved. The author is particularly grateful to Associate Professor Suzanne Donnelly for introducing her to rheumatology and encouraging her to pursue the Academic Track Internship. Special thanks are extended to Professor Geraldine McCarthy and Dr John Stack, for their invaluable supervision, insightful feedback and unwavering support which were instrumental in shaping this research. Finally, the author thanks Joe for his encouragement and steadfast support throughout the course of this work.

fn.p: Funding: This work was supported by Trinity College Dublin Academic Track Internship Bursary (€2000), which funded conference-related expenses to present this study.

Patient consent for publication: Not applicable.
Data availability free text: Additional data (eg, anonymised audit tables) are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: Raw data are available on reasonable request. All data relevant to the study are included in the article or uploaded as supplementary information.
